thread.title: Jetstar cancels flights to and from Bali
thread.title_full: Jetstar cancels flights to and from Bali

title: Jetstar cancels flights to and from Bali
text:
What are these? Eruption ... Mount Raung in Java has erupted, sending an ash cloud as far as 10 kilometres, and 3,500km into the air. Picture: Instagram Source: Instagram 
A VOLCANIC eruption in Bali has forced Jetstar to cancel several flights in and out of the island overnight. 
The airline issued a statement about 11:30pm yesterday telling passengers that an ash cloud from the Mount Raung eruption in Indonesia was drifting towards Denpasar International Airport. — Jetstar Airways (@JetstarAirways) July 2, 2015 
“We regret the disruption this weather event has caused our passengers, and thank them for their patience as we work to provide alternative options,” Jetstar said in a statement . 
“All passengers on rescheduled or cancelled flights will be notified by Jetstar or their Travel Agent directly and provided with options to fly on alternative services.” 
Indonesian authorities raised the alert after an eruption at Mount Raung caused ash to coat villages as far as 10 kilometres away. Customer care ... Customers are being urged to change their flights to Bali within seven days to avoid a fee charge. Picture: AFP Sonny/Tumbelaka Source: News Limited 
Jetstar has listed several options available to those holding a July 2 or July 3 ticket, and urges passengers to contact its customer centre within seven days of their intended travel time, free of charge. 
According to News Asia , the volcanic eruption could be heard 20 kilometres away. Pilots also reported seeing ash 3.5 kilometres in the air. 
Authorities cordoned off a two-kilometre radius around the volcano, and raised the alert level to “Siaga”— the second highest level. Safety concerns ... Jetstar has since cancelled most flights in and our of Bali. Picture: Instagram Source: Instagram 
The Head of Prevention and Disaster Preparedness at the local Natural Disaster Mitigation Agency said that the eruption could be seen from a lookout post in Banyuwangi, East Java. 
Volcanologists have recorded an increase in volcanic activity and tremors on the 3,332-metre high Mount Raung since June 24.
